size doesn't much matter to me.  I never in that big of a hurry anymore.  Thanks for the share.

should note though that most people do not need a 1080p file.  Average laptops are 1280 width for basic models.   A lot of the TV's in use are probably 720p TV's.  Unless you have a newer 1080p television then there isn't much benefit for you to get the 1080p file.  You also need some way of watching the 1080p file natively.  The 2010 model samsung LED tv's play MKV 1080p with DTS audio natively with the builtin media player.  Its a good choice if you are thinking of upgrading.  The first gen Samsung LED tv only supported AC3 audio (though that could be fixed in a firmware push now).

Best way to play these files on a HDTV is via something like LaCie cinema connect HD connected to TV via HDMI + optical to a surround sound system.  Download movies directly to a portable HD and then either stream or connect HD directly to the LaCie with a simple USB lead - plays like a dream!! Thanks for these quality downloads.

The movie was shot with an aspect ratio of 2.400:1, so yes, 1920x800 is 1080p. It would only have a screen resolution of 1920x1080 if the mattes/letterbox were kept, or encoded into to video file itself - do you homework.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letterbox

Cheers for the upload, aoloffline.
